awd_titl_txt: Rapid, Selective, Onsite Detection of Bacterial Pathogens Using A Bioinspired Microfluidic Sensor
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to create a high-throughput microfluidic biosensor for rapid, onsite, highly-selective detection of a variety of food and water borne bacterial pathogens. The approach is to employ an innovative biotin-streptavidin based immunoaffinity recognition method for real time bacterial pathogen recognition, and a multiplexed parallel sensing array for rapid detection. 
The intellectual merit is to enable a transformative experimental tool for rapid analysis of bacterial pathogens because of the high throughput, high selectivity and high sensitivity of the sensor.  The immunoaffinity recognition based on streptavidin-biotin interaction is label free, requires only one universal surface modification with biotin, and can be used for detecting many bacterial pathogens. Thus it will lead to a transformative technology for low cost, onsite detection of bacterial pathogens and cells. Research on multiplexation of signals from parallel microfluidic channels will yield a generalized platform for developing high throughput biosensors.  
The broader Impacts are multifold. The proposed research will have transformative impacts on food and drinking water safety monitoring, environmental monitoring, bio-warfare detection, and clinical diagnosis.  This project will provide interdisciplinary training opportunity for the graduate and undergraduate students involved in the research. The project also aims to develop lab-on-a-chip and bio-nanotechnology related educational materials and contribute to motivating undergraduate students and K-12 students to pursue science and engineering careers. Through University of Akron?s ?Increasing Diversity in Engineering Academics?, ?Women in Engineering? and ?High School Bridge? programs, undergraduate students and high school students will be recruited to conduct research in this project.

por.por_cntn:
Rapid, onsite detection of bacterial pathogens represents an important task for many scientific fields such as food safety and drinking water monitoring, environmental monitoring, bio-warfare detection and clinical diagnosis. While culture and colony counting methods still remain the standard method for bacterial pathogen detection, this method is low-throughput and excessively time-consuming, requiring a long pre-enrichment step and lab-intensive ocular inspection/enumeration.  

With the funding from National Science Foundation, researchers at University of Akron have successfully demonstrated an innovative pathogen cell detection method based on the immunoaggregation assay.  With this method, antibody-conjugated microparticles are used to functionalize the surface of a capture chamber to capture the pathogen cells; and two resistive pulse sensors were used to count cells before and after the capture chamber.  The count difference between the two sensors represents the population of pathogen cells.  This detection method is label free, eliminates the need to chemically modify the surface of microchannels, and yet has high sensitivity and specificity, making it particularly suitable for onsite applications that need rapid pathogen cell but lack immediate access to analytical instruments.

In terms of scientific impact, the single cell detection capability, high throughput, and high selectivity of the sensor, along with its low cost and portability, make it a practical tool for rapid analysis of a variety of bacterial pathogens. Along with the high throughput and portability, the sensor is particularly suitable for field applications because it has long shelf life and the recognition surface can be quickly regenerated after one use.  It is a powerful complement to PCR and ELISA for pathogen sensing. The bioassay method can potentially be applied for detection of a wide variety of other biological targets such as bacteria, biospores, cancer cells and virus in liquid environment, which will lead to improved food and water safety, public health, and enhanced homeland security.  This method can be easily adapted for both fully equipped hospitals/labs and remote clinics/labs with limited access to analytical instrument.  It will undoubtedly have broad impacts on environmental monitoring, biodefense, clinical diagnosis, and biological research.

In terms of education and outreach, the research activities were highly multi-disciplinary, involving microfluidics, BioMEMS, biosensing, multiplexing, and provided educational experiences for the students and faculty members involved in the project. During the project, six graduate students and 7 undergraduate students participated in the research. Two high school students were involved in the research activities, who chose engineering as their major in college. Two high school teachers were also exposed to biosensor research. Research results were included in two classes offered to graduate students and senior undergraduate students, and delivered to high school girls during their summer visit.
